Pioneer Address: VENN, SASK

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realise that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

The extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

(Signed)
MEMORIOUS VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes? How often did you usually visit neighbors?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Frequently

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? At any time

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? 

That about meal? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Or was it necessary that two all the supper we shared being a lot?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? How was this term to "take potatoes" used, or was some other expression common?

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to watch after the house?

6. Did you ever have "spells" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the spells were for and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, what drives or dances in homes? Describe, generally not enough written for dancing or what drives cards were used for the games.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates, especially not enough written for dancing or what drives cards were used for the games.

Did you follow any kind of informal schemes, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.? Isolation caused the custom to not come again and at polling it was the custom to not come again.

It has been said a bachelor trifled the word to decide what was working and to hang over to be on time for the meal. It was wonderful how resourceful a manly settler improvised limited provisions for a meal.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTYING, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many homes were bachelor households? How many of these were bachelor households?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Frequently, occasionally, rarely?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays, or other days? At what time?

4. Have you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without invitation?

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? 

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Or was the occasion that day all the people were having a meal together?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had some unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to cook after the dinner? Or was there a separate meal for the children?

6. Did you ever have these meetings at someone's house? Or did they take place in a building, like a schoolhouse, or another public building? Tell what you remember about such gatherings. If possible, tell what the "beast" were for and how often they happened.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in honor? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates, between which years? How old were adults around for conveniences? Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times—every two weeks, once a month, etc.? If so, did you change the custom to only come again and at pacing it was the custom to only come twice?

It has been said a bachelor prefers the word to decide what was working and to hurry over to town time for the meal. It has been noted that provisions for the married settler improved limited provisions for a unmarried settler.

How were babies and small children provided for? With diapers for a fence?

How were hoppers sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? A team of horses hitched to a sleigh would be used to transport the hoppers from the barn to the hall.

There was no liquor in the beginning, but later there were at times religious sects living among the neighbors and had a mental attitude over some horrible tales and the results to the community. I should agree to stop immediately to work by starvation etc.

School was used for all purposes listed in 69 and for a grain growers association meeting place and for the distribution of commodities by cooperation.

70. Was the school yard used for school or community picnics, ball games, etc.? Describe.

The annual picnic of three schools Bloomfield, Thorntown, and Boulder Lake was in the yard and a Mr. Paulson MPL of Wymond constituency arrived and wanted to address the gathering but was not allowed as he was very intoxicated. Our special speakers topic was progress and achievement by B. B. Munsellman.

71. What differences were there in the way the school was conducted in the first years you were here as compared with the country you came from?

Teachers frequently misspelled and handwriting is very poor and the term "I see" quite common also. Schedule for schedule general knowledge vague and they have forgotten lots they should know.
